docs.lead_paragraph: During a year in which the Summer Olympics will extend into autumn, the American track and field stars are being careful to pace their ambitions and their speed. There is no sense to be in top form in late April when the Olympics do not begin until mid-September. Still, Marion Jones and Michael Johnson flashed through impressive checkpoints today at the Penn Relays. Jones anchored an American team in the seldom-run 4x200-meter relay to a world record in 1 minute 27.46 seconds. Johnson anchored an American 4x400-meter team that set a Penn Relays record, 2:56.6.

headline.main: Jones and Johnson Help Set Records

docs.abstract: Penn Relays continue, Philadelphia; results noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From the outside, the old Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx looks much as it did 20, or 70, years ago: blond brick, lots of it, coating the neo-Renaissance facade of an 11-story building that takes up much of a square block. But inside, there are no patients, or doctors, or nurses, no emergency room or maternity ward. What was the ambulance garage is a fitness center; where rabbits were once used for pregnancy tests, there is a community room; what was a waiting room is now a lobby, with a lunch kiosk, for a community economic development center.

headline.main: Bronx Journal; Once a Hospital and Again an Anchor

docs.abstract: Bronx building that was Morrisania Hospital until it closed 20 years ago is converted into 132 apartments for low-income and formerly homeless families; also houses Urban Horizons Center which offers residents of neighborhood array of social services; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Just over two years ago, the veteran sailor J. J. Isler joined forces with her former rival and fellow Californian Pease Glaser in a bid to secure the slot on the United States sailing team for the women's 470 class in the Olympics in Sydney, Australia, this September. Isler, a two-time Rolex yachtswoman of the year and a bronze medalist in the doublehanded 470 at the 1992 Games in Barcelona, Spain, believed that she had a firm understanding of the obstacles that lay ahead.

headline.main: These Olympic Hurdles Are a Much Different Kind

docs.abstract: J J Isler discusses qualifying for US Olympic sailing team that will compete in 200 Summer Games; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was only 7:30 a.m. when a group of Republican loyalists began gathering today at Bailey's Coffee and News, but it was not too early for State Representative Leo Daughtry to start calling his opponent for governor, Richard Vinroot, a liberal. Mr. Vinroot has been criticized by the National Rifle Association as a gun-control advocate, Mr. Daughtry said. Mr. Vinroot is pro-choice, Mr. Daughtry said. Mr. Vinroot proposed a tax increase while he was mayor of Charlotte, Mr. Daughtry said. ''I think all those add up to being a liberal,'' he concluded.

headline.main: Tight Races for Governor in N. Carolina

docs.abstract: Race for Republican nomination for governor of North Carolina between State Representative Leo Daughtry and Richard Vinroot has become charge toward right, with candidates showing little restraint, and often little concern for facts, in painting each other as closet liberals; recent polls show Vinroot, mayor of Charlotte from 1991 to 1995, with small lead over Daughtry, Smithfield lawyer and businessman who was once majority leader of state House, with former State representative Chuck Neely trailing; Atty Gen Mike Easley has narrow lead over Lt Gov Dennis Wicker in Democratic contest; both share similar stands on major issues (M)
